column5: The Bloody Mary is a foundational savory cocktail that pairs vodka with the umami density of tomato juice and a custom spice blend. Unlike sweet sours, it relies on Worcestershire sauce, celery salt, and hot sauce for a rich, culinary profile. Lemon juice provides necessary acid to cut through the heavy texture, making it a balanced restorative drink. It is the defining cocktail of American brunch culture, allowing for significant garnish variation while maintaining its core tomato-spice structure.

Without juniper to mask the spirit, the drink demands a clean, oily vodka and precise dilution to avoid tasting harsh. Dry vermouth adds a subtle saline character that extends the finish. It became the dominant style of Martini in American culture during the mid-20th century, favored for its neutrality and cold, crisp profile.

column4: A tart grapefruit-vodka highball defined by a salted rim.
column5: The Salty Dog is essentially a Greyhound served with a salted rim, which materially changes the flavor profile. The salt suppresses the grapefruit's natural bitterness, enhancing the perception of citrus sweetness without adding sugar. While originally a gin drink, the vodka variation became standard by the mid-20th century. Built over ice, it is a cooling, savory-tart highball ideal for hot weather.

Replacing gin’s botanicals with vodka shifts the focus toward bright lime acidity, resulting in a sharper, more straightforward sour. It serves as a benchmark for the quality of the lime cordial or fresh juice used. The drink is served up and icy cold, emphasizing the clean texture of the spirit.

The blue curaçao provides the defining electric color and a slightly bitter orange backbone that plays against the neutral vodka. It is a mid-century European classic that predates the neon disco drinks of the 80s.

The result is a balanced, fruit-forward highball with a vibrant coral hue. It became a staple of American bar menus in the 1980s alongside the Sea Breeze and Bay Breeze. column5: The Bull Shot is a savory cocktail that functions as a cold soup or restorative draught, popular in mid-century country clubs. It amplifies the umami of beef bouillon with Worcestershire sauce, lemon, and hot sauce, similar to a Bloody Mary but lighter in texture. It gained immense popularity in South America and Europe as a cleaner, more accessible alternative to the rustic original. column5: The Chrysanthemum is an elegant stirred cocktail that uses dry vermouth as the base spirit, fortified with the honeyed herbs of Bénédictine and the anise of absinthe. Despite having no hard liquor base, it is complex, aromatic, and full-bodied. It showcases how vermouth can stand as a protagonist rather than just a modifier. It is a floral, spring-like sipper that was popular on transatlantic cruise liners.
column6: Stir a Chrysanthemum with dry vermouth, Bénédictine, and absinthe.

column24: The recipe was popularized by Harry Craddock in the *Savoy Cocktail Book* (1930), highlighting the era's appreciation for lower-proof, aromatic drinks.
column27: 2 oz dry vermouth|1 oz Bénédictine|3 dashes absinthe
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir until well chilled. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with an orange twist.

column4: A nutty, aromatic stirred cocktail of sherry and dry vermouth.
column5: The Coronation is a classic aperitif that reads like a lower-proof Martini. It splits the base between Fino sherry and dry vermouth, modified with maraschino liqueur and orange bitters. The result is bone-dry, saline, and savory, with a nutty oxidized character from the sherry. It is an intellectual sipper, perfect for stimulating the appetite without dulling the senses.
column6: Stir a Coronation with Fino sherry, dry vermouth, and maraschino.
column12: A Coronation in a Nick & Nora glass with a lemon twist.
column23: Use Fino or Manzanilla sherry for the crispest profile; darker sherries will make it too heavy.
column24: Created to celebrate the coronation of King Edward VII in 1902, making it a literal celebratory cocktail.
column27: 2 oz Fino sherry|1 oz dry vermouth|0.25 oz maraschino liqueur|2 dashes orange bitters
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir until well chilled. 3. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass. 4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

column4: A simple, elegant French aperitif of white wine and blackcurrant liqueur.
column5: The Kir is the foundational French aperitif, combining dry acidic white wine (traditionally Aligoté) with the dark berry sweetness of crème de cassis. Unlike the Kir Royale (made with Champagne), the still wine version is more humble and widely consumed in French homes and cafés. The cassis creates a beautiful reddish-purple hue and softens the wine's acidity. It is a study in two-ingredient balance.
column6: Build a Kir with dry white wine and crème de cassis.
column12: A Kir in a wine glass showing a soft purple gradient.
column23: Put the cassis in the glass first, then pour the wine; this helps them mix without needing to stir aggressively.
column24: Named after Félix Kir, the mayor of Dijon and hero of the French Resistance, who promoted the drink to showcase the region's two main products: white wine and blackcurrants.
column27: 0.5 oz crème de cassis|5 oz dry white wine (Aligoté or Sauvignon Blanc)
column28: 1. Pour crème de cassis into a wine glass. 2. Top with chilled white wine. 3. Serve immediately (no ice).

column4: A refreshing Andalusian mix of sherry, lemon-lime soda, and mint.
column5: The Rebujito is the staple drink of the the Ferias (fairs) in Southern Spain, offering a lighter, more refreshing alternative to Sangria. It mixes salty, dry Manzanilla sherry with sweet lemon-lime soda (like 7-Up or Sprite) and plenty of fresh mint. The result is a crushable, effervescent highball that cuts through the heat of an Andalusian summer. It is low in alcohol but high in hydration and flavor.
column6: Build a Rebujito with Manzanilla sherry, soda, and mint.
column12: A Rebujito in a highball glass with mint and a lemon wheel.
column23: Do not muddle the mint; just slap it to release oils, keeping the drink crisp and clean.
column24: While relatively modern compared to sherry itself, it has completely supplanted other mixed drinks at the Seville April Fair due to its refreshing nature.
column27: 2 oz Manzanilla sherry|4 oz lemon-lime soda (Sprite or 7Up)|Fresh mint sprig
column28: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice. 2. Add sherry and soda. 3. Stir gently. 4. Slap a sprig of mint to release aromatics and add to the glass. 5. Garnish with a lemon wheel.

column4: A 19th-century classic showcasing sweet vermouth as the primary spirit.
column5: The Vermouth Cocktail is a relic of the era when vermouth was drunk neat or with minimal modification. It treats sweet vermouth as the base spirit, stirring it with Angostura bitters and a touch of maraschino or curaçao. It brings out the complex botanicals of the fortified wine—vanilla, wormwood, and spices—that are often lost when mixed with whiskey. It is a gentle, aromatic aperitif.
column6: Stir a Vermouth Cocktail with sweet vermouth and bitters.
column12: A Vermouth Cocktail in a chilled coupe with a lemon twist.
column23: Dilution is key; because vermouth is lower proof than whiskey, be careful not to over-dilute with wet ice.
column24: This was one of the first 'cocktails' (spirit, sugar, water, bitters) to use a wine base, appearing in manuals as early as 1869.
column27: 2.5 oz sweet vermouth (Italian style)|2 dashes Angostura bitters|1 dash Maraschino liqueur (optional)
column28: 1. Add vermouth, bitters, and maraschino to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir well to chill. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

column4: A savory, spicy Mexican beer cocktail with lime and sauces.
column5: The Michelada is a savory beer cocktail that functions as a refresher and a restorative. It dresses up a light Mexican lager with fresh lime juice and a custom blend of savory sauces (Worcestershire, soy, Maggi, hot sauce), served in a glass with a salted chili rim. It is essentially a Bloody Mary made with beer instead of tomato juice (though 'Michelada Cubana' versions add tomato). It is savory, tart, effervescent, and umami-rich.
column6: Build a Michelada with Mexican lager, lime, and savory sauces.
column12: A Michelada in a pint glass with a red chili-salt rim.
column23: Adjust the hot sauce and savory seasonings to taste; there is no single 'correct' ratio.
column24: The name is a contraction of 'mi chela helada' (my cold beer), reflecting its function as the ultimate way to dress up a cold lager.

column28: 1. Rim a pint glass with lime and Tajín (or salt). 2. Fill the glass with ice. 3. Add lime juice and sauces. 4. Pour the beer slowly over the ice. 5. Stir gently to combine. 6. Garnish with a lime wedge.

column4: A stirred vermouth blend created as a low-ABV homage to Andrew Jackson.
column5: The Old Hickory is a sophisticated low-ABV cocktail that blends equal parts dry and sweet vermouth, seasoned with both orange and Peychaud's bitters. It drinks like a lighter, wine-based Manhattan, offering complexity from the interplay of the two vermouth styles. It is named after Andrew Jackson ('Old Hickory') and dates back to the turn of the 20th century. It is a perfect sessionable sipping drink for those who love stirred cocktails.
column6: Stir an Old Hickory with dry and sweet vermouth.
column12: An Old Hickory in a coupe with a lemon twist.
column23: Use high-quality vermouths (like Dolin and Carpano) since there is no spirit to hide behind.
column24: The drink serves as a lighter alternative to the Bamboo or Adonis, notable for using Peychaud's bitters which gives it a slight creole aromatic lift.

column28: 1. Add both vermouths and bitters to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir until well chilled. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

column4: A Prohibition-era sour masking absinthe with orange and grenadine.
column5: The Monkey Gland is a historic sour that uses the sweetness of grenadine and orange juice to tame the anise punch of an absinthe rinse. While the name refers to a bizarre 1920s pseudo-scientific longevity treatment, the drink itself is a sophisticated, fruity gin cocktail. It balances the botanical heat of London Dry gin with a soft, confectionary finish. It is a staple of the Harry's New York Bar canon in Paris.
column6: Shake a Monkey Gland with gin, orange juice, absinthe, and grenadine.
column12: A Monkey Gland in a chilled coupe with an orange twist.
column23: Use fresh orange juice and high-quality pomegranate grenadine; artificial syrup makes this drink cloying.
column24: Named after Dr. Serge Voronoff's controversial experiment of grafting monkey testicle tissue into humans to achieve longevity—a sensation in 1920s Paris.
column27: 2 oz gin|1 oz fresh orange juice|0.25 oz grenadine|Absinthe for rinse
column28: 1. Rinse a chilled coupe with absinthe and discard excess. 2. Add gin, orange juice, and grenadine to a shaker with ice. 3. Shake well. 4. Strain into the prepared glass. 5. Garnish with an orange twist.

column4: A golden, herbal martini riff featuring Yellow Chartreuse.
column5: The Alaska is a spirit-forward variation of the Martini that swaps dry vermouth for Yellow Chartreuse. This substitution adds honeyed, herbal, and saffron notes to the gin, creating a drink that is colder and more golden than the original. It is often dashed with orange bitters to bridge the gap between the piney gin and the liqueur. The drink is potent and aromatic, representing the 'Golden Age' of cocktail experimentation.
column6: Stir an Alaska cocktail with gin and Yellow Chartreuse.
column12: An Alaska in a Nick & Nora glass with a lemon twist.
column23: Yellow Chartreuse is milder and sweeter than Green; using Green Chartreuse makes a completely different drink (the Jewel).
column24: Despite the cold name, the drink likely originated in South Carolina before being immortalized in the *Savoy Cocktail Book* as a cooling drink for high society.
column27: 1.5 oz gin|0.5 oz Yellow Chartreuse|1 dash orange bitters
column28: 1. Add gin, Yellow Chartreuse, and bitters to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir until very cold. 3. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass. 4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

column4: A complex, jewel-toned trio of gin, sweet vermouth, and Green Chartreuse.
column5: The Bijou (French for 'Jewel') is a rich, herbal cocktail named for the colors of its components: gin for diamond, sweet vermouth for ruby, and Green Chartreuse for emerald. It drinks like a heavy, herbal Negroni, with a thick mouthfeel and intense aromatic profile. It is a slow-sipping classic that showcases the power of Chartreuse when used in equal (or near-equal) measure. It dates back to the 1890s but found new life in the modern craft revival.
column6: Stir a Bijou cocktail with gin, vermouth, and Green Chartreuse.
column12: A Bijou in a coupe with a lemon twist and cherry.
column23: The traditional 1:1:1 ratio can be overwhelming; modern palates often prefer a 1.5:1:1 or 2:1:1 ratio to let the gin shine.
column24: The drink's name specifically references the jewels represented by the ingredients: diamond (gin), ruby (vermouth), and emerald (Chartreuse).
column27: 1.5 oz gin|1 oz sweet vermouth|1 oz Green Chartreuse|1 dash orange bitters
column28: 1. Add ingredients to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir well to chill and dilute. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a lemon twist and cherry.

column4: A bone-dry, sugar-free highball of gin, lime, and soda.
column5: The Gin Rickey is the definition of a dry heat-wave cooler. Unlike the Collins, which contains sugar, the Rickey relies entirely on the interplay between the botanical gin, tart lime, and mineral soda water. It was originally made with bourbon, but the gin variation became the global standard for refreshing, non-sweet highballs. It is traditionally served with the spent lime shell in the glass to continue releasing oils.
column6: Build a Gin Rickey with gin, lime, and soda water.
column12: A Gin Rickey in a highball glass with a lime half-shell submerged.
column23: Squeeze the lime half and drop the entire shell into the glass; the rind's oils are essential to the flavor profile.
column24: The drink was created at Shoomaker's bar in Washington D.C. in the 1880s for lobbyist Colonel Joe Rickey, famously a 'sugar-hater'.

column28: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice. 2. Squeeze the lime juice into the glass and drop in the shell. 3. Add gin. 4. Top with soda water and stir briefly.

column4: A modern classic Gin Sour defined by the addition of Angostura bitters.
column5: The Fitzgerald is a modern classic that essentially fixes the Gin Sour by adding Angostura bitters. This small addition provides a cinnamon-clove depth that anchors the lemon and sugar, preventing the drink from tasting like simple lemonade. It serves as the 'sour' counterpart to the 'spirit-forward' Gin Old Fashioned. It is widely considered the best way to serve a shaken gin drink without egg white.
column6: Shake a Fitzgerald with gin, lemon, sugar, and bitters.
column12: A Fitzgerald in a rocks glass with a lemon wedge.
column23: Named after author F. Scott Fitzgerald, fitting for a drink that feels like a Jazz Age classic despite being created in the 1990s.
column24: Created by Dale DeGroff at the Rainbow Room in New York in the 1990s to give a name to a requested 'Gin Sour with bitters.'
column25: Dale DeGroff, The Craft of the Cocktail

column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice. 4. Garnish with a lemon wedge.

column4: A historic 'perfect' martini lengthened with fresh orange juice.
column5: The Bronx was the Cosmopolitan of the pre-Prohibition era—the first cocktail to popularize the use of fruit juice in a martini-style build. It combines gin with both sweet and dry vermouth (a 'perfect' base) and fresh orange juice. The result is a soft, low-acid drink that bridges the gap between an aperitif and a fruit cocktail. While it fell out of fashion for decades, it remains a critical piece of cocktail history.
column6: Shake a Bronx cocktail with gin, two vermouths, and orange juice.
column12: A Bronx cocktail in a coupe with an orange twist.
column23: Use freshly squeezed orange juice; bottled juice makes this drink taste flat and muddy.
column24: In the early 1900s, the Bronx was so popular that it was widely considered the primary rival to the Manhattan and Martini.

column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well to chill and aerate. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with an orange twist.

column4: A dry, sophisticated martini riff with maraschino and absinthe.
column5: The Turf Club is an Old School martini variation that dates back to the 1880s. It modifies the gin and dry vermouth base with small measures of maraschino liqueur, absinthe, and orange bitters. These additions dry out the drink further while adding nutty and anise notes, creating a profile that is much more complex than a standard Dry Martini. It is the definition of a 'bartender's martini'.
column6: Stir a Turf Club with gin, dry vermouth, and maraschino.
column12: A Turf Club in a Nick & Nora glass with a lemon twist.
column23: The 'Turf Club' name was used for several different recipes; the 1884 version with maraschino and absinthe is the most enduring.
column24: Named after the famous Turf Club gentlemen's society in New York, a hub for horse racing enthusiasts and drinkers in the Gilded Age.
column27: 2 oz gin|1 oz dry vermouth|0.25 oz maraschino liqueur|2 dashes absinthe|2 dashes orange bitters
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir until very cold. 3. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass. 4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

column4: A refined, orange-laced variation of the Negroni with dry vermouth.
column5: The Lucien Gaudin is a French answer to the Negroni that replaces sweet vermouth with dry vermouth and adds Cointreau. This shift creates a lighter, drier, and more orange-focused drink that retains the bitter spine of Campari. It is less syrupy than a Negroni, making it an excellent aperitif for those who find the Italian original too heavy. It balances bitter, dry, and sweet citrus notes perfectly.
column6: Stir a Lucien Gaudin with gin, Campari, Cointreau, and dry vermouth.
column12: A Lucien Gaudin in a coupe with an orange twist.
column23: High-proof gin works best here to cut through the two liqueurs and the Campari.
column24: Named after a famous French fencer who won gold medals at the 1924 and 1928 Olympics, reflecting the drink's sharp, precise nature.
column27: 1.5 oz gin|0.5 oz Campari|0.5 oz Cointreau|0.5 oz dry vermouth
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir until well chilled. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with an orange twist.

column4: A tropical tiki-style gin sour with falernum and Cointreau.
column5: The Royal Bermuda Yacht Club is a rare example of a tiki-adjacent drink that uses gin instead of rum. It pairs the spirit with velvet falernum (a spiced lime cordial) and Cointreau, creating a profile that is spicy, citrusy, and refreshing. It shares DNA with the Daiquiri but offers the botanical complexity of gin. It was popularized by Trader Vic, proving that gin has a place in tropical mixology.

column12: A Royal Bermuda Yacht Club in a coupe with a lime wheel.

column24: While originating at the actual Yacht Club in Bermuda, the recipe became famous globally after appearing in Trader Vic's 1947 *Bartender's Guide*.

column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake vigorously to chill. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

column4: A dry, crisp mix of gin, dry vermouth, and grapefruit juice.
column5: The Gibb Cocktail is a forgotten gem that acts as a drier, sharper cousin to the Bronx. It combines gin and dry vermouth with fresh grapefruit juice (rather than orange), creating a profile that is bracingly tart and savory. It appeals to drinkers who find orange juice too sweet in cocktails. It is lean, aromatic, and distinctly pre-Prohibition in style.
column6: Shake a Gibb Cocktail with gin, dry vermouth, and grapefruit.
column12: A Gibb Cocktail in a cocktail glass with a grapefruit twist.
column23: Use white or pink grapefruit juice; ruby red may be too sweet for the intended dryness.
column24: The drink appears in the *Savoy Cocktail Book* but remains obscure compared to its orange-juice counterparts.

column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a chilled cocktail glass. 4. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

column4: A sophisticated, herbal martini variation with Bénédictine.
column5: The Poet's Dream is an elegant riff on the Dry Martini that swaps a portion of the vermouth for Bénédictine. This introduces honey, herbs, and spices to the juniper base, creating a drink that is aromatic and contemplative. Unlike the Alaska, it retains the dry vermouth, keeping the profile closer to a fortified wine cocktail than a liqueur drink. It is a smooth, spirit-forward sipper.
column6: Stir a Poet's Dream with gin, dry vermouth, and Bénédictine.
column12: A Poet's Dream in a Nick & Nora glass with a lemon twist.
column23: Express the lemon oils over the drink to brighten the heavy herbal notes of the Bénédictine.
column24: The drink won a cocktail competition in London in 1935, capturing the romanticism of the pre-war era.
column27: 2 oz gin|0.75 oz dry vermouth|0.25 oz Bénédictine|2 dashes orange bitters
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice. 2. Stir until very cold. 3. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass. 4. Garnish with a lemon twist.

column4: A complex, layered sour with Green Chartreuse and Aperol.
column5: The Gypsy Eyes is a modern classic that bridges the gap between the Last Word and a Gin Sour. It modifies the gin and lime base with Green Chartreuse and Aperol (or sometimes Campari), creating a reddish-pink drink with deep herbal complexity. It balances the medicinal punch of Chartreuse with the bittersweet orange of the aperitivo. It is a bartender favorite for its intricate flavor map.
column6: Shake a Gypsy Eyes with gin, Green Chartreuse, and Aperol.
column12: A Gypsy Eyes in a coupe with a rosemary sprig.
column23: Sometimes made with grapefruit juice alongside the lime for added depth.
column24: Often attributed to the modern craft cocktail revival in San Francisco, showcasing the versatility of mixing Chartreuse with other modifiers.

column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a rosemary sprig.

column4: A Gimlet variation that adds Angostura bitters and omits the cordial.
column5: The Bennett is essentially a Gin Gimlet made with fresh lime and simple syrup (instead of cordial), seasoned heavily with Angostura bitters. It strips away the cooked-sugar taste of Rose's Lime Juice, replacing it with the fresh bite of citrus and the spice of bitters. It is a cleaner, sharper, and more aromatic version of the mid-century standard. It proves that bitters belong in sours.
column6: Shake a Bennett with gin, lime, sugar, and bitters.
column12: A Bennett in a coupe with a lime wheel.
column23: This is the ancestor of the modern 'Fresh Gimlet,' dating back to the 1920s.
column24: Named after a well-to-do American expatriate in Chile who preferred his Gimlets fresh and spiced, rather than with preserved cordial.
column27: 2 oz gin|1 oz fresh lime juice|0.75 oz simple syrup|2 dashes Angostura bitters
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

column4: A bitters-heavy riff on the Bronx cocktail.
column5: The Income Tax is essentially a Bronx cocktail (Gin, Sweet & Dry Vermouth, Orange Juice) with the addition of Angostura bitters. The bitters dry out the orange juice and add a spicy depth that makes the drink feel more 'adult' and less like a breakfast beverage. It is a forgotten classic that offers a balanced, low-ABV option with a cynical name.
column6: Shake an Income Tax with gin, vermouths, orange juice, and bitters.
column12: An Income Tax cocktail in a coupe with an orange twist.
column23: The bitters are the defining ingredient; without them, it is just a Bronx.
column24: The drink's name reflects the era of its popularity (1920s), coinciding with the rising complexity of American tax laws.

column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with an orange twist.

column4: A minty, herbal gin sour with a dash of crème de menthe.
column5: The Fallen Angel is a peculiar but delightful classic that adds a dash of white crème de menthe and Angostura bitters to a standard gin and lime sour. The mint is used as a seasoning rather than a main flavor, providing a cooling finish that plays against the juniper. It is less sweet than a Grasshopper and more complex than a Southside. It represents the 'seasoning' style of pre-Prohibition mixing.
column6: Shake a Fallen Angel with gin, lime, and crème de menthe.
column12: A Fallen Angel in a coupe with a mint leaf.
column23: Use white crème de menthe to keep the drink looking crisp; green will turn it a muddy color.
column24: The name implies a corrupted innocence, fitting for a drink that looks like a pure Gimlet but tastes of medicinal mint and bitters.

column28: 1. Add ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a mint leaf.

column4: A spicy, towering highball of tequila, crème de cassis, and ginger beer.
column5: El Diablo is a mid-century classic that balances the earthy heat of tequila with the deep berry sweetness of crème de cassis and the spice of ginger beer. Unlike the Margarita, which focuses on citrus, this drink is savory, spicy, and fruity all at once. The cassis sinks to the bottom (or is mixed in) to create a dark, devilish hue. It is one of the few tiki-era tequila drinks that has stood the test of time.

column12: An El Diablo in a highball glass with a lime wedge.

column24: The recipe first appeared in Trader Vic's *Book of Food and Drink* (1946), proving that tequila had a place in the tiki canon.

column28: 1. Shake tequila, cassis, and lime juice with ice. 2. Strain into a highball glass filled with fresh ice. 3. Top with ginger beer. 4. Garnish with a lime wedge.

column4: A cult-favorite Mexican highball of tequila, cola, and salt.
column5: The Batanga is the rustic cousin of the Cuba Libre, swapping rum for blanco tequila and adding a distinct salted rim. Created in the town of Tequila, Mexico, it is defined by its method of being stirred with a large knife used to cut the limes. The salt bridges the gap between the sugary cola and the vegetal agave, creating a savory-sweet profile that is incredibly drinkable. It is unpretentious and deeply traditional.

column4: A smoky, earthier riff on the classic Italian aperitivo.
column5: The Mezcal Negroni swaps gin for mezcal, instantly transforming the drink from botanical to smoky and savory. The agave spirit stands up powerfully to the bitterness of Campari and the richness of sweet vermouth, creating a profile that is deeper and more brooding than the original. It is arguably the most successful modern variation of the Negroni, becoming a standard call in bars worldwide.

column4: A modern classic balancing smoke, citrus, and herbal liqueurs.
column5: The Naked and Famous is an equal-parts sour that serves as a mezcal-based cousin to the Last Word and Paper Plane. It combines mezcal, Yellow Chartreuse, Aperol, and lime juice into a complex, orange-hued drink. The smokiness of the mezcal cuts through the sweetness of the liqueurs, while the Chartreuse adds an herbal backbone. It is a masterclass in four-ingredient balance.
column6: Shake a Naked and Famous with mezcal, Chartreuse, Aperol, and lime.

column23: Using a high-proof mezcal helps the base spirit shine through the heavy modifiers.

column27: 0.75 oz mezcal|0.75 oz Yellow Chartreuse|0.75 oz Aperol|0.75 oz fresh lime juice

column4: A visual 70s icon of tequila, orange juice, and sinking grenadine.
column5: The Tequila Sunrise is defined by its gradient appearance, mimicking a sunrise through the density difference between orange juice and grenadine. While often dismissed as a disco drink, a well-made version using fresh juice and quality tequila is a solid, refreshing highball. It relies on the agave to provide a backbone to the sweet fruit. It is the drink that defined the aesthetic of 1970s California rock and roll.
column6: Build a Tequila Sunrise with tequila, orange juice, and grenadine.
column12: A Tequila Sunrise in a highball glass with a red-to-yellow gradient.
column23: Pour the grenadine vigorously so it hits the bottom and rises up, creating the effect.
column24: The modern version was created at the Trident in Sausalito in the 1970s and became famous after the Rolling Stones adopted it as the official drink of their 1972 tour.
column27: 2 oz tequila blanco|4 oz fresh orange juice|0.5 oz grenadine
column28: 1. Fill a highball glass with ice. 2. Add tequila and orange juice. 3. Pour grenadine directly into the center of the glass (do not stir). 4. Garnish with an orange slice and cherry.

column4: A smoky, aperitivo-style sour with mezcal and maraschino.
column5: The Division Bell is a modern classic that modifies the Last Word template, pairing mezcal with Aperol and maraschino liqueur. Unlike the Naked and Famous, it leans nuttier and dryer due to the maraschino. It showcases how mezcal pairs exceptionally well with bitter orange and cherry notes. It is bright red, smoky, and dangerously sessionable.
column6: Shake a Division Bell with mezcal, Aperol, maraschino, and lime.
column12: A Division Bell in a coupe with a grapefruit twist.
column23: Express the grapefruit oils over the drink to highlight the citrus notes in the Aperol.
column24: Created by Phil Ward at Mayahuel in New York, a bar pivotal in introducing artisanal mezcal cocktails to the US market.
column27: 1 oz mezcal|0.75 oz Aperol|0.5 oz maraschino liqueur|0.75 oz fresh lime juice
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.

column4: A vibrant pink sour of tequila, lime, grenadine, and bitters.
column5: The Mexican Firing Squad is a historic cocktail from the 1930s that essentially serves as a Margarita with grenadine instead of triple sec, seasoned heavily with Angostura bitters. The bitters cut the sweetness of the pomegranate syrup and add a savory, spiced depth to the agave base. It is pink, tart, and complex, offering a different path for tequila sours. It proves that tequila and bitters are natural partners.
column6: Shake a Mexican Firing Squad with tequila, lime, and grenadine.
column12: A Mexican Firing Squad in a rocks glass with a lime wheel.
column23: Use homemade grenadine (pomegranate juice and sugar) for a rich flavor; bright red bottled syrup will make it taste like candy.
column24: Discovered by historian Charles H. Baker in Mexico City in 1937, who described it as a drink that 'invokes no desire to engage in pistol practice.'
column25: Charles H. Baker, Gentleman's Companion; Imbibe
column27: 2 oz tequila blanco|0.75 oz fresh lime juice|0.75 oz grenadine|4 dashes Angostura bitters
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake vigorously. 3. Strain into a rocks glass filled with fresh ice. 4. Garnish with a lime wheel.

column4: A simple, shaken mix of tequila, pineapple, and lime.
column5: The Matador is one of the three primary tequila classics (alongside the Margarita and Sunrise), pairing the spirit with pineapple juice. It lacks the carbonation of a highball, drinking more like a stiff sour. The pineapple's acidity and foam structure complement the vegetal tequila perfectly. It is a streamlined, less sweet alternative to tiki drinks.
column6: Shake a Matador with tequila, pineapple, and lime.
column12: A Matador in a coupe or rocks glass with a pineapple wedge.
column23: Shake vigorously to create a frothy head from the pineapple juice.
column24: The Matador appeared in the 1937 *Café Royal Cocktail Book*, establishing pineapple as a key partner for tequila long before the tiki boom.
column25: Café Royal Cocktail Book; Difford's Guide
column27: 2 oz tequila blanco or reposado|2 oz fresh pineapple juice|0.75 oz fresh lime juice|0.5 oz simple syrup (optional)
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe or rocks glass. 4. Garnish with a pineapple wedge.

column4: A rustic citrus punch served in a clay pot.
column5: The Cantarito is the authentic roadside cooler of Jalisco, blending tequila with a mix of orange, grapefruit, and lime juices, topped with grapefruit soda. Traditionally served in a clay cup (cantarito) which keeps the drink impossibly cold and adds an earthy aroma. It is more complex and citrus-forward than a Paloma, with a pinch of salt to tie the juices together. It is the ultimate refreshing agave punch.
column6: Build a Cantarito with tequila and three citrus juices in a clay mug.
column12: A Cantarito in a clay mug rimmed with chili salt.
column23: If you don't have a clay mug, a highball glass works, but soaking the clay pot in water first is the traditional cooling method.
column24: The porous clay of the traditional vessel allows for evaporation that cools the liquid inside, an ancient refrigeration technique.
column27: 2 oz tequila reposado|1 oz fresh orange juice|1 oz fresh grapefruit juice|0.5 oz fresh lime juice|Grapefruit soda (Squirt or Jarritos) to top
column28: 1. Rim a clay mug or glass with chili salt (Tajín). 2. Fill with ice. 3. Add tequila and fresh juices. 4. Top with grapefruit soda. 5. Stir to combine. 6. Garnish with citrus wedges.

column4: A modern classic mashup of the Hemingway Daiquiri and the Paloma.
column5: The Siesta is a sophisticated modern sour that uses Campari and grapefruit juice to modify a tequila base. It reads like a drier, bitterer Margarita with a beautiful coral hue. The bitterness of the Campari serves to tighten the structure of the drink, preventing the fruit juices from feeling flabby. It has become a standard 'bartender's choice' for guests who like tequila but want something adventurous.
column6: Shake a Siesta with tequila, Campari, grapefruit, and lime.
column12: A Siesta in a coupe with a grapefruit twist.
column23: Fresh grapefruit juice is non-negotiable here; the bitterness of the pith is essential to the balance.
column24: Created by Katie Stipe at the Flatiron Lounge in New York in 2006, it was one of the first modern classics to successfully mix tequila and Campari.
column27: 1.5 oz tequila blanco|0.5 oz Campari|0.5 oz fresh grapefruit juice|0.5 oz fresh lime juice|0.5 oz simple syrup
column28: 1. Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice. 2. Shake well to chill. 3. Strain into a chilled coupe. 4. Garnish with a grapefruit twist.
